RSV: “ships of Kittim,” NIV: “Ships of the western coastlands,” NKJV: “ships from Cyprus,” NIRV: “Roman ships,” NLT: “warships from western coastlands.” The Bible has been translated into Latin since the earliest days of the Church, so this Latin text (Trieres, et Romani) may be based on some ancient manuscripts, in Hebrew or Greek, which are not now extant.
 The Trieres is a type of warship used by the ancient Greeks. But in Daniel, Greece symbolizes democracy, since that is where democracy first began. So, giving the text a modern interpretation, these warships are from an area which still, at that time in the future, practices some form of democracy. But, though the ships are Greek ships, the crew is Roman, which in the modern context would refer to Roman Catholics (or to Christians in general during a future time when all Christians are united in one Church). This interpretation explains why the Antichrist is indignant against Christianity after his defeat and why he sets out to destroy the Faith about halfway through his reign. Daniel 9:27 refers to this time of half a week of years.
 The Antichrist then consults the adversaries of the Christians, those who have abandoned the Christian faith.

verses.textEn: And arms will take his side, and they will pollute the sanctuary of the strength, and they will take away the continual sacrifice and will replace it with the abomination of desolation.
verses.textLa: Et brachia ex eo stabunt, et polluent sanctuarium fortitudinis, et auferent iuge sacrificium: et dabunt abominationem in desolationem.
verses.notes: Here again the word strength is used to refer to Christianity, as in the sanctuary of the strength, which will be polluted by the abomination of desolation (a false Eucharist). The continual sacrifice is the Eucharist.

verses.textEn: And the impious within the testament will imitate deceitfully, but the people, knowing their God, will persevere and will act.
verses.textLa: Et impii in testamentum simulabunt fraudulenter: populus autem sciens Deum suum, obtinebit, et faciet.

verses.textEn: And the teachers among the people will teach many, but they will be ruined by the sword, and by fire, and by captivity, and by assaults for many days.
verses.textLa: Et docti in populo docebunt plurimos: et ruent in gladio, et in flamma, et in captivitate, et in rapina dierum.
verses.notes: The word rapina can mean sexual assault. In other contexts, rapina tends more towards robbery or even the loot obtained by robbery, but in this context rapina refers to physical assaults of various kinds.

verses.textEn: And when they have fallen, they will be supported with a little help, but many will apply to them deceitfully.
verses.textLa: Cumque corruerint, sublevabuntur auxilio parvulo: et applicabuntur eis plurimi fraudulenter.

verses.textEn: And some of the learned will be ruined, that they may be kindled and chosen and purified, up to the predetermined time, because there will be still another time.
verses.textLa: Et de eruditis ruent, ut conflentur, et eligantur, et dealbentur usque ad tempus præfinitum: quia adhuc aliud tempus erit.
verses.notes: The learned are not pure and on fire with the love of God; but some will be brought to this by suffering. Not many, just some. The very learned tend not to be very faithful nor very holy.

verses.textEn: And the king will act according to his will, and he will be lifted up and will be extolled against every god. And he will speak great things against the God of gods, and he will control, until the passion is completed. Once accomplished, the limit is reached with certainty.
verses.textLa: Et faciet iuxta voluntatem suam rex, et elevabitur, et magnificabitur adversus omnem deum: et adversus Deum deorum loquetur magnifica, et dirigetur, donec compleatur iracundia: perpetrata quippe est definitio.
verses.notes: The word “iracundia” can refer to anger and is sometimes translated in this context as wrath, that is, until the wrath of God is completed. But such a translation does not fit the context well. The verse is about the Antichrist exalting himself, and acting according to his ill will, and controlling the world, and blaspheming God. This is not yet the Wrath of God on the unrepentant wicked. In this context, the phrase refers to the Passion of the Church, that is, to the great sufferings of the faithful during the reign of the Antichrist.

verses.textEn: And he will give no thought to the God of his fathers, and he will be in the desire of women, and he will not attend to any gods, because he will rise up against all things.
verses.textLa: Et Deum patrum suorum non reputabit: et erit in concupiscentiis feminarum, nec quemquam deorum curabit: quia adversum universa consurget:
verses.notes: The phrase “erit in concupiscentiis feminarum” does not mean that he will lust after women, but that women will lust for him.

verses.textEn: But he will do homage to the god Maozim in his place, and, a god whom his fathers did not know, he will worship with gold, and silver, and precious stones, and costly things.
verses.textLa: deum autem Maozim in loco suo venerabitur: et deum, quem ignoraverunt patres eius, colet auro, et argento, et lapide pretioso, rebusque pretiosis.

verses.textEn: And he will act to reinforce Maozim with an alien god, of whom he has become aware, and he will increase their glory, and will give them power over many, and he will distribute land for free.
verses.textLa: Et faciet ut muniat Maozim cum deo alieno, quem cognovit, et multiplicabit gloriam, et dabit eis potestatem in multis, et terram dividet gratuito.

verses.textEn: And, at the predetermined time, the king of the South will fight against him, and the king of the North will come against him like a tempest, with chariots, and with horsemen, and with a great fleet, and he will enter into the lands, and will crush and pass through.
verses.textLa: Et in tempore præfinito prœliabitur adversus eum rex Austri, et quasi tempestas veniet contra illum rex Aquilonis in curribus, et in equitibus, et in classe magna, et ingredietur terras, et conteret, et pertransiet.

verses.textEn: And he will enter into the glorious land, and many will fall. But only these will be saved from his hand: Edom, and Moab, and the first part of the sons of Ammon.
verses.textLa: Et introibit in terram gloriosam, et multæ corruent: hæ autem solæ salvabuntur de manu eius, Edom, et Moab, et principium filiorum Ammon.
verses.notes: The illustrious land, terra inclyta, (Dan 11:16) is probably a different land than the glorious land, terram gloriosam. The glorious land appears to be Israel, the holy land.

verses.textEn: And he will cast his hand upon the lands, and the land of Egypt will not escape.
verses.textLa: Et mittet manum suam in terras: et terra Ægypti non effugiet.

verses.textEn: And he will rule over the treasure chests of gold, and silver, and all the precious things of Egypt, and likewise he will pass through Libya and Ethiopia.
verses.textLa: Et dominabitur thesaurorum auri, et argenti, et in omnibus pretiosis Ægypti: per Libyam quoque, et Æthiopiam transibit.

verses.textEn: And rumors from the East and from the North will trouble him. And he will arrive with a great multitude to destroy and to execute many.
verses.textLa: Et fama turbabit eum ab Oriente et ab Aquilone: et veniet in multitudine magna ut conterat et interficiat plurimos.
verses.notes: Fama is rumors, or news, or reports. The word interficiat implies that the killing is an execution, from governmental authority (whether legitimate or not), and not a killing in battle.

verses.textEn: And he will fasten his tabernacle, Apadno, between the seas, upon an illustrious and holy mountain, and he will come even to its summit, and no one will help him.”
verses.textLa: Et figet tabernaculum suum Apadno inter maria, super montem inclytum et sanctum: et veniet usque ad summitatem eius, et nemo auxiliabitur ei.
verses.notes: Again, illustrious would seem to indicate a different land than the glorious land of Israel.

verses.textEn: “But at that time Michael will rise up, the great leader, who stands up for the sons of your people. And a time will come, such as has not been from the time that nations began, even until that time. And, at that time, your people will be saved, all who will be found written in the book.
verses.textLa: In tempore autem illo consurget Michael princeps magnus, qui stat pro filiis populi tui: et veniet tempus quale non fuit ab eo ex quo gentes esse cœperunt usque ad tempus illud. Et in tempore illo salvabitur populus tuus, omnis qui inventus fuerit scriptus in libro.

verses.textEn: And many of those who sleep in the dust of the earth will awaken: some to everlasting life, and others to a reproach that they will always see.
verses.textLa: Et multi de his, qui dormiunt in terræ pulvere, evigilabunt: alii in vitam æternam, et alii in opprobrium ut videant semper.

verses.textEn: But those who have taught will shine like the brightness of the firmament, and those who instruct many towards justice, like the stars for unending eternity.
verses.textLa: Qui autem docti fuerint, fulgebunt quasi splendor firmamenti: et qui ad iustitiam erudiunt multos, quasi stellæ in perpetuas æternitates.

verses.textEn: But you, Daniel, close the message and seal the book, until the established time. Many will pass through, and knowledge will be increased.”
verses.textLa: Tu autem Daniel claude sermones, et signa librum usque ad tempus statutum: plurimi pertransibunt, et multiplex erit scientia.
verses.notes: The phrase “plurimi pertransibunt” refers to the passage of time. Many generations will pass through between the time of Daniel and the events of his visions.

verses.textEn: And I, Daniel, looked, and behold, similarly two others stood up, one over here, on the bank of the river, and the other over there, on the other bank of the river.
verses.textLa: Et vidi ego Daniel, et ecce quasi duo alii stabant: unus hinc super ripam fluminis, et alius inde ex altera ripa fluminis.

verses.textEn: And I said to the man, who was clothed in linen, who stood over the waters of the river, “How long will it be until the end of these wonders?”
verses.textLa: Et dixi viro, qui erat indutus lineis, qui stabat super aquas fluminis: Usquequo finis horum mirabilium?

verses.textEn: And I heard the man, who was clothed in linen, who stood over the waters of the river, when he had lifted his right hand and his left hand up to heaven, and had sworn by He who lives forever, that it would be for a time, and times, and half a time. And when the dispersion of the hand of the holy people is completed, all these things will be completed.
verses.textLa: Et audivi virum, qui indutus erat lineis, qui stabat super aquas fluminis, cum elevasset dexteram et sinistram suam in cælum, et iurasset per Viventem in æternum, quia in tempus, et tempora, et dimidium temporis. Et cum completa fuerit dispersio manus populi sancti, complebuntur universa hæc.
verses.notes: The word manus, usually translated as hand, can also mean a band or small group of people, especially soldiers.

verses.textEn: And I heard and did not understand. And I said, “My lord, what will be after these things?”
verses.textLa: Et ego audivi, et non intellexi. Et dixi: Domine mi, quid erit post hæc?

verses.textEn: And he said, “Go, Daniel, for the words are closed and sealed until the predetermined time.
verses.textLa: Et ait: Vade Daniel, quia clausi sunt, signatique sermones usque ad præfinitum tempus.

verses.textEn: Many will be chosen and purified, and, as if by fire, they will be tested, and the impious will act impiously, and none of the impious will understand, yet the teachers will understand.
verses.textLa: Eligentur, et dealbabuntur, et quasi ignis probabuntur multi: et impie agent impii, neque intelligent omnes impii, porro docti intelligent.

verses.textEn: And from the time when the continual sacrifice will be taken away and the abomination of desolation will be set up, there will be one thousand two hundred ninety days.
verses.textLa: Et a tempore cum ablatum fuerit iuge sacrificium, et posita fuerit abominatio in desolationem, dies mille ducenti nonaginta.

verses.textEn: Blessed is he who waits and reaches until one thousand three hundred thirty-five days.
verses.textLa: Beatus, qui expectat, et pervenit usque ad dies mille trecentos trigintaquinque.

verses.textEn: But you, go, until the predetermined time, and you will rest and will stand in your allotted place at the end of days.
verses.textLa: Tu autem vade ad præfinitum: et requiesces, et stabis in sorte tua in finem dierum.

verses.textEn: And there was a man living in Babylon, and his name was Joakim.
verses.textLa: Et erat vir habitans in Babylone, et nomen eius Ioakim:

verses.textEn: And he received a wife named Susanna, the daughter of Hilkiah, who was very beautiful and God-fearing.
verses.textLa: Et accepit uxorem nomine Susannam, filiam Helciæ pulchram nimis, et timentem Deum:

verses.textEn: For her parents, because they were righteous, had educated their daughter according to the law of Moses.
verses.textLa: parentes enim illius, cum essent iusti, erudierunt filiam suam secundum legem Moysi.

verses.textEn: But Joakim was very wealthy, and he had an orchard near his house, and the Jews flocked to him, because he was the most honorable of them all.
verses.textLa: Erat autem Ioakim dives valde, et erat ei pomarium vicinum domui suæ: et ad ipsum confluebant Iudæi, eo quod esset honorabilior omnium.

verses.textEn: And two elder judges had been appointed among the people that year, about whom the Lord has said, “Iniquity has come out of Babylon, from the elder judges, who seemed to govern the people.”
verses.textLa: Et constituti sunt de populo duo senes iudices in illo anno: de quibus locutus est Dominus: Quia egressa est iniquitas de Babylone a senioribus iudicibus, qui videbantur regere populum.
verses.notes: One of the terms used to describe these two judges is “senes iudices,” elder judges.

verses.textEn: These frequented the house of Joakim, and all came to them, who had need of judgment.
verses.textLa: Isti frequentabant domum Ioakim, et veniebant ad eos omnes, qui habebant iudicia.

verses.textEn: But when the people departed at noontime, Susanna went in and walked around in her husband’s orchard.
verses.textLa: Cum autem populus revertisset per meridiem, ingrediebatur Susanna, et deambulabat in pomario viri sui.
verses.notes: Deambulabat means to walk around or to take a walk, it does not merely mean walking.

verses.textEn: And the elders saw her entering and walking around every day, and they were inflamed with desire towards her.
verses.textLa: Et videbant eam senes quotidie ingredientem, et deambulantem: et exarserunt in concupiscentiam eius:

verses.textEn: And they perverted their reason and turned away their eyes, so that they would not look to heaven, nor call to mind just judgments.
verses.textLa: et everterunt sensum suum, et declinaverunt oculos suos ut non viderent cælum, neque recordarentur iudiciorum iustorum.
verses.notes: Sensum can also mean mind or understanding.

verses.textEn: And so they were both wounded by the love of her, yet they did not reveal their grief to one another.
verses.textLa: Erant ergo ambo vulnerati amore eius, nec indicaverunt sibi vicissim dolorem suum:

verses.textEn: For they were ashamed to reveal to each other their desire, wanting to lie with her.
verses.textLa: erubescebant enim indicare sibi concupiscentiam suam, volentes concumbere cum ea:
verses.notes: Here is one way to refer to sexual relations: concumbere, to lie with (someone).

verses.textEn: And so they watched carefully every day to see her. And one said to the other,
verses.textLa: et observabant quotidie solicitius videre eam. Dixitque alter ad alterum:

verses.textEn: “Let us go home, for it is lunch time.” And going out, they departed one from another.
verses.textLa: Eamus domum, quia hora prandii est. Et egressi recesserunt a se.

verses.textEn: And returning again, they came to the same place, and, each asking the other the reason, they admitted their desire. And then they agreed to set a time when they would be able to find her alone.
verses.textLa: Cumque revertissent, venerunt in unum: et sciscitantes ab invicem causam, confessi sunt concupiscentiam suam: et tunc in communi statuerunt tempus, quando eam possent invenire solam.

verses.textEn: But it happened, while they watched for an opportune day, that she entered at a particular time, just as yesterday and the day before, with only two maids, and she wanted to wash in the orchard, because it was so hot.
verses.textLa: Factum est autem, cum observarent diem aptum, ingressa est aliquando sicut heri et nudiustertius, cum duabus solis puellis, voluitque lavari in pomario: æstus quippe erat:
verses.notes: The word quippe means “of course” or “naturally” or “as you see.” Literally, the phrase says “it was, of course, very hot.”

verses.textEn: And there was no one there, except the two elders in hiding, and they were studying her.
verses.textLa: et non erat ibi quisquam, præter duos senes absconditos, et contemplantes eam.

verses.textEn: And so she said to the maids, “Bring me oil and ointments, and shut the doors of the orchard, so that I may wash.”
verses.textLa: Dixit ergo puellis: Afferte mihi oleum, et smegmata, et ostia pomarii claudite, ut laver.
verses.notes: The word smegmata is obscure, translated as “washing balls” by the Douay-Rheims and, alternately, as “ointments.” It refers to whatever type of soap or other substance the persons of that time and place used to wash themselves.

verses.textEn: And they did as she ordered them. And they shut the doors of the orchard and left through a back door to fetch what she required, and they did not know that the elders were hiding within.
verses.textLa: Et fecerunt sicut præceperat: clauseruntque ostia pomarii, et egressæ sunt per posticum ut afferrent quæ iusserat: nesciebantque senes intus esse absconditos.

verses.textEn: But when the maids had departed, the two elders arose and hurried to her, and they said,
verses.textLa: Cum autem egressæ essent puellæ, surrexerunt duo senes, et accurrerunt ad eam, et dixerunt:

verses.textEn: “Behold, the doors of the orchard are closed, and no one can see us, and we are in desire for you. Because of these things, consent to us and lie with us.
verses.textLa: Ecce ostia pomarii clausa sunt, et nemo nos videt, et nos in concupiscentia tui sumus: quam ob rem assentire nobis, et commiscere nobiscum.
verses.notes: Here is another way to refer to sexual relations: commiscere, to intermingle or to unite.

verses.textEn: But if you will not, we will bear witness against you that a young man was with you and, for this reason, you sent your maids away from you.”
verses.textLa: Quod si nolueris, dicemus contra te testimonium, quod fuerit tecum iuvenis, et ob hanc causam emiseris puellas a te.

verses.textEn: Susanna sighed and said, “I am closed in on every side. For if I do this thing, it is death to me; yet if I do not do it, I will not escape your hands.
verses.textLa: Ingemuit Susanna, et ait: Angustiæ sunt mihi undique: si enim hoc egero, mors mihi est: si autem non egero, non effugiam manus vestras.

verses.textEn: But it is better for me to fall unavoidably into your hands, than to sin in the sight of the Lord.”
verses.textLa: Sed melius est mihi absque opere incidere in manus vestras, quam peccare in conspectu Domini.

verses.textEn: And Susanna cried out with a loud voice, but the elders also cried out against her.
verses.textLa: Et exclamavit voce magna Susanna: exclamaverunt autem et senes adversus eam.

verses.textEn: And one of them hurried to the door of the orchard and opened it.
verses.textLa: Et cucurrit unus ad ostia pomarii, et aperuit.
verses.notes: So the door was closed, which would not be the case if a young man had just been chased out of it.

verses.textEn: And so, when the servants of the house heard the outcry in the orchard, they rushed in by the back door to see what was happening.
verses.textLa: Cum ergo audissent clamorem famuli domus in pomario, irruerunt per posticum ut viderent quidnam esset.

verses.textEn: But after the old men had spoken, the servants were greatly ashamed, for there had never been anything of this kind said about Susanna. And it happened on the next day,
verses.textLa: Postquam autem senes locuti sunt, erubuerunt servi vehementer: quia numquam dictus fuerat sermo huiuscemodi de Susanna. Et facta est dies crastina:

verses.textEn: when the people came to Joakim her husband, that the two appointed elders also came, full of wicked plans against Susanna, in order to put her to death.
verses.textLa: cumque venisset populus ad Ioakim virum eius, venerunt et duo presbyteri pleni iniqua cogitatione adversus Susannam ut interficerent eam.
verses.notes: Here the elders are referred to as “presbyteri,” a word which could be translated as elders, but which indicates that these were elders who were appointed to a position of leadership, appointed elders.

verses.textEn: And they said before the people, “Send for Susanna, daughter of Hilkiah, the wife of Joakim.” And immediately they sent for her.
verses.textLa: Et dixerunt coram populo: Mittite ad Susannam filiam Helciæ uxorem Ioakim. Et statim miserunt.

verses.textEn: And she arrived with her parents, and sons, and all her relatives.
verses.textLa: Et venit cum parentibus, et filiis, et universis cognatis suis.
verses.notes: The word cognatis means relatives, but resembles the word for knowing, and so, it is those who knew her well.

verses.textEn: Moreover, Susanna was exceedingly delicate and beautiful in appearance.
verses.textLa: Porro Susanna erat delicata nimis, et pulchra specie.

verses.textEn: But those wicked ones commanded that her face should be uncovered, (for she was covered,) so that at least they might be satisfied with her beauty.
verses.textLa: At iniqui illi iusserunt ut discooperiretur (erat enim cooperta) ut vel sic satiarentur decore eius.
verses.notes: Now the elders are referred to as iniqui, wicked ones.

verses.textEn: Therefore, her own and all who knew her wept.
verses.textLa: Flebant igitur sui, et omnes qui noverant eam.

verses.textEn: Yet the two appointed elders, rising up in the midst of the people, set their hands upon her head.
verses.textLa: Consurgentes autem duo presbyteri in medio populi, posuerunt manus suas super caput eius.
verses.notes: They not only uncovered her face, they dared to touch her, thus showing their lack of chastity and self-restraint by their actions.

verses.textEn: And weeping, she gazed up to heaven, for her heart had faith in the Lord.
verses.textLa: Quæ flens suspexit ad cælum: erat enim cor eius fiduciam habens in Domino.

verses.textEn: And the appointed elders said, “While we were taking a walk in the orchard alone, this one came in with two maids, and she shut the doors of the orchard, and she sent the maids away from her.
verses.textLa: Et dixerunt presbyteri: Cum deambularemus in pomario soli, ingressa est hæc cum duabus puellis: et clausit ostia pomarii, et dimisit a se puellas.

verses.textEn: And a young man came to her, who was in hiding, and he lay down with her.
verses.textLa: Venitque ad eam adolescens, qui erat absconditus, et concubuit cum ea.
verses.notes: Again, sexual relations is referred to with the word concubuit, to lie with someone.

verses.textEn: Furthermore, since we were in a corner of the orchard, seeing this wickedness, we ran up to them, and we saw them consorting together.
verses.textLa: Porro nos cum essemus in angulo pomarii, videntes iniquitatem, cucurrimus ad eos, et vidimus eos pariter commisceri.
verses.notes: Now the word commisceri, to intermingle is used to refer to sexual relations. Both of these expressions are somewhat euphemistic: to lie together or to intermingle. But both expressions are also fairly blunt and show, in the social and religious context of this story, that the elders are unchaste and unrestrained with their words.

verses.textEn: And, indeed, we were unable to catch him, because he was stronger than us, and opening the doors, he leaped out.
verses.textLa: Et illum quidem non quivimus comprehendere, quia fortior nobis erat, et apertis ostiis exilivit:

verses.textEn: But, since we had apprehended this one, we demanded to know who the young man was, but she was unwilling to tell us. On this matter, we are witnesses.”
verses.textLa: hanc autem cum apprehendissemus, interrogavimus, quisnam esset adolescens, et noluit indicare nobis: huius rei testes sumus.

verses.textEn: The multitude believed them, just as if they were elders and the judges of the people, and they condemned her to death.
verses.textLa: Credidit eis multitudo quasi senibus et iudicibus populi, et condemnaverunt eam ad mortem.

verses.textEn: But Susanna cried out with a loud voice and said, “Eternal God, who knows what is hidden, who knows all things before they happen,
verses.textLa: Exclamavit autem voce magna Susanna, et dixit: Deus æterne, qui absconditorum es cognitor, qui nosti omnia antequam fiant,

verses.textEn: you know that they have borne false witness against me, and behold, I must die, though I have done none of these things, which these men have maliciously invented against me.”
verses.textLa: tu scis quoniam falsum testimonium tulerunt contra me: et ecce morior, cum nihil horum fecerim, quæ isti malitiose composuerunt adversum me.
verses.notes: Susanna shows her chastity and self-restraint by not even repeating explicitly the charge against herself.

verses.textEn: But the Lord heeded her voice.
verses.textLa: Exaudivit autem Dominus vocem eius.

verses.textEn: And when she was led away to death, the Lord raised up the holy spirit of a young boy, whose name was Daniel.
verses.textLa: Cumque duceretur ad mortem, suscitavit Dominus spiritum sanctum pueri iunioris, cuius nomen Daniel:

verses.textEn: And he cried out with a loud voice, “I am clean of the blood of this one.”
verses.textLa: Et exclamavit voce magna: Mundus ego sum a sanguine huius.

verses.textEn: And all the people, turning back towards him, said, “What is this word that you are saying?”
verses.textLa: Et conversus omnis populus ad eum, dixit: Quis est iste sermo, quem tu locutus es?

verses.textEn: But he, while standing in the midst of them, said, “Are you so foolish, sons of Israel, that without judging and without knowing what the truth is, you have condemned a daughter of Israel?
verses.textLa: Qui cum staret in medio eorum, ait: Sic fatui filii Israel, non iudicantes, neque quod verum est cognoscentes, condemnastis filiam Israel?

verses.textEn: Return to judgment, because they have spoken false witness against her.”
verses.textLa: Revertimini ad iudicium, quia falsum testimonium locuti sunt adversus eam.

verses.textEn: Therefore, the people returned with haste, and the old men said to him, “Come and sit down in our midst and show us, since God has given you the honor of old age.”
verses.textLa: Reversus est ergo populus cum festinatione, et dixerunt ei senes: Veni, et sede in medio nostrum, et indica nobis: quia tibi Deus dedit honorem senectutis.

verses.textEn: And Daniel said to them, “Separate these at a distance from one another, and I will judge between them.”
verses.textLa: Et dixit ad eos Daniel: Separate illos ab invicem procul, et diiudicabo eos.

verses.textEn: And so, when they were divided, one from the other, he called one of them, and he said to him, “You deep-rooted ancient evil, now your sins have come out, which you have committed before,
verses.textLa: Cum ergo divisi essent alter ab altero, vocavit unum de eis, et dixit ad eum: Inveterate dierum malorum, nunc venerunt peccata tua, quæ operabaris prius:
verses.notes: “Inveterate dierum malorum” translates somewhat loosely as “deep-rooted ancient evil.” More literally, dierum means a long time, malorum means evil or harmful, and inveterate means to become old or to become rooted or to become hardened by age.

verses.textEn: judging unjust judgments, oppressing the innocent, and setting free the guilty, though the Lord declares, ‘The innocent and the just you must not put to death.’
verses.textLa: iudicans iudicia iniusta, innocentes opprimens, et dimittens noxios, dicente Domino: Innocentem et iustum non interficies.

verses.textEn: Now then, if you saw her, declare under which tree you saw them conversing together.” He said, “Under an evergreen mastic tree.”
verses.textLa: Nunc ergo si vidisti eam, dic sub qua arbore videris eos colloquentes sibi. Qui ait: Sub schino.
verses.notes: This tree is a short evergreen tree found in the Middle East. Notice that Daniel shows more discretion than the elders in the language he uses to describe sexual relations. He uses the more euphemistic and more discrete term “colloquentes sibi.” The term conversation was used by Flavius Josephus to denote sexual relations. It is an ancient euphemistic expression.

verses.textEn: But Daniel said, “Truly, you have lied against your own head. For behold, the angel of God, having received the sentence from him, will split you down the middle.
verses.textLa: Dixit autem Daniel: Recte mentitus es in caput tuum: Ecce enim Angelus Dei accepta sententia ab eo, scindet te medium.

verses.textEn: And, having put him aside, he commanded the other to approach, and he said to him, “You offspring of Canaan, and not of Judah, beauty has deceived you, and desire has perverted your heart.
verses.textLa: Et, amoto eo, iussit venire alium, et dixit ei: Semen Chanaan, et non Iuda, species decepit te, et concupiscentia subvertit cor tuum:

verses.textEn: Thus did you do to the daughters of Israel, and they, out of fear, consorted with you, but a daughter of Judah would not tolerate your iniquity.
verses.textLa: sic faciebatis filiabus Israel, et illæ timentes loquebantur vobis: sed filia Iuda non sustinuit iniquitatem vestram.
verses.notes: Again, Daniel uses a term referring to conversation, loquebantur, to refer to sexual relations. He does the same in the next verse also.

verses.textEn: Now then, declare to me, under which tree you caught them conversing together.” He said, “Under an evergreen oak tree.”
verses.textLa: Nunc ergo dic mihi, sub qua arbore comprehenderis eos loquentes sibi. Qui ait: Sub prino.

verses.textEn: And Daniel said to him, “Truly, you also have lied against your own head. For the angel of the Lord waits, holding a sword, to cut you down the middle and put you to death.”
verses.textLa: Dixit autem ei Daniel: Recte mentitus es et tu in caput tuum: manet enim Angelus Domini, gladium habens, ut secet te medium, et interficiat vos.
verses.notes: Note that “interficiat” refers to execution by authority and that “vos” is plural. Daniel is saying that God will execute both of these elders for their false testimony against Susanna.

verses.textEn: And then the entire assembly cried out in a loud voice, and they blessed God, who saves those who hope in him.
verses.textLa: Exclamavit itaque omnis cœtus voce magna, et benedixerunt Deum, qui salvat sperantes in se.

verses.textEn: And they rose up against the two appointed elders, (for Daniel had convicted them, by their own mouth, of bearing false witness,) and they did to them just as they had wickedly done against their neighbor,
verses.textLa: Et consurrexerunt adversus duos presbyteros (convicerat enim eos Daniel ex ore suo falsum dixisse testimonium) feceruntque eis sicut male egerant adversus proximum,

verses.textEn: so as to act according to the law of Moses. And they put them to death, and innocent blood was saved on that day.
verses.textLa: ut facerent secundum legem Moysi: et interfecerunt eos, et salvatus est sanguis innoxius in die illa.

verses.textEn: But Hilkiah and his wife praised God for their daughter, Susanna, with Joakim, her husband, and all her relatives, because there had been found in her no disgrace.
verses.textLa: Helcias autem et uxor eius laudaverunt Deum pro filia sua Susanna cum Ioakim marito eius, et cognatis omnibus, quia non esset inventa in ea res turpis.

verses.textEn: And so Daniel became great in the sight of the people from that day, and thereafter.
verses.textLa: Daniel autem factus est magnus in conspectu populi a die illa, et deinceps.

verses.textEn: And king Astyages was laid to rest with his fathers. And Cyrus the Persian received his kingdom.
verses.textLa: Et rex Astyages appositus est ad patres suos, et suscepit Cyrus Perses regnum eius.

verses.textEn: And so Daniel was living with the king, and he was honored above all his friends.
verses.textLa: Erat autem Daniel conviva regis, et honoratus super omnes amicos eius.

verses.textEn: Now there was an idol with the Babylonians named Bel. And each day there was expended on him twelve great measures of fine flour, and forty sheep, and six vessels of wine.
verses.textLa: Erat quoque idolum apud Babylonios nomine Bel: et impendebantur in eo per dies singulos similæ artabæ duodecim, et oves quadraginta, vinique amphoræ sex.
verses.notes: Artabae is an Egyptian unit of measure equivalent to 3.5 Roman measures or about 7 gallons.

verses.textEn: The king likewise worshipped him and went each day to adore him, but Daniel adored his God. And the king said to him, “Why do you not adore Bel?”
verses.textLa: Rex quoque colebat eum, et ibat per singulos dies adorare eum: porro Daniel adorabat Deum suum. Dixitque ei rex: Quare non adoras Bel?

verses.textEn: And answering, he said to him, “Because I do not worship idols made with hands, but the living God, who created heaven and earth, and who holds power over all flesh.”
verses.textLa: Qui respondens, ait ei: Quia non colo idola manufacta, sed viventem Deum, qui creavit cælum, et terram, et habet potestatem omnis carnis.

verses.textEn: And the king said to him, “Does not Bel seem to you to be a living god? Do you not see how much he eats and drinks every day?”
verses.textLa: Et dixit rex ad eum: Non videtur tibi esse Bel vivens Deus? An non vides quanta comedat, et bibat quotidie?

verses.textEn: Then Daniel said, smiling, “O king, do not make a mistake, for this one is clay on the inside and brass on the outside, and he has never eaten.”
verses.textLa: Et ait Daniel arridens: Ne erres rex: iste enim intrinsecus luteus est, et forinsecus æreus, neque comedit aliquando.

verses.textEn: And the king, being angry, called for his priests and said to them, “If you do not tell me who it is that has eaten these expenses, you will die.
verses.textLa: Et iratus rex vocavit sacerdotes eius, et ait eis: Nisi dixeritis mihi, quis est qui comedat impensas has, moriemini.

verses.textEn: But if you can show that Bel has eaten these, Daniel will die, because he has blasphemed against Bel.” And Daniel said to the king, “Let it be according to your word.”
verses.textLa: Si autem ostenderitis, quoniam Bel comedat hæc, morietur Daniel, quia blasphemavit in Bel. Et dixit Daniel regi: Fiat iuxta verbum tuum.
verses.notes: Fiat means “let it be” or “let it be done” or “may it be done.” The form of the word is subjunctive, present tense.

verses.textEn: Now the priests of Bel were seventy, besides their wives, and little ones, and sons. And the king went with Daniel into the temple of Bel.
verses.textLa: Erant autem sacerdotes Bel septuaginta, exceptis uxoribus, et parvulis, et filiis. Et venit rex cum Daniele in templum Bel.
verses.notes: The word filiis literally means sons, but is sometimes used to refer to a group of children, including both boys and girls. The male term is used to denote both males and female, as in mankind (or man), or brethren, because men are intended by God to be leaders in the Church, the family, and society.

verses.textEn: And the priests of Bel said, “Behold, we are going out, and you, O king, set out the meats, and mix the wine, and close the door, and seal it with your ring.
verses.textLa: Et dixerunt sacerdotes Bel: Ecce nos egredimur foras: et tu rex pone escas, et vinum misce, et claude ostium, et signa annulo tuo:
verses.notes: The wine is most likely mixed with water. The use of the term “mix the wine” might seem strange, but in ancient times they mixed wine with water. The alcohol purified the water and the water prevented the wine from too easily causing drunkenness.

verses.textEn: And when you have entered in the morning, if you have not found that Bel has consumed all, we will suffer death, or else Daniel will, who has lied against us.”
verses.textLa: et cum ingressus fueris mane, nisi inveneris omnia comesta a Bel, morte moriemur, vel Daniel qui mentitus est adversum nos.

verses.textEn: But they had no concern because they had made a secret entrance under the table, and they always went in through it and devoured those things.
verses.textLa: Contemnebant autem, quia fecerant sub mensa absconditum introitum, et per illum ingrediebantur semper, et devorabant ea.

verses.textEn: And so it happened, after they had departed, that the king set the foods before Bel, and Daniel commanded his servants, and they brought ashes, and he sifted them throughout the temple in the sight of the king, and, as they left, they shut the door, and after sealing it with the king’s ring, they departed.
verses.textLa: Factum est igitur postquam egressi sunt illi, rex posuit cibos ante Bel: præcepit Daniel pueris suis, et attulerunt cinerem, et cribravit per totum templum coram rege: et egressi clauserunt ostium: et signantes annulo regis abierunt.

verses.textEn: But the priests entered by night, according to their custom, with their wives, and their sons, and they ate and drank everything.
verses.textLa: Sacerdotes autem ingressi sunt nocte iuxta consuetudinem suam, et uxores et filii eorum: et comederunt omnia, et biberunt.

verses.textEn: But the king arose at first light, and Daniel with him.
verses.textLa: Surrexit autem rex primo diluculo, et Daniel cum eo.

verses.textEn: And the king said, “Are the seals unbroken, Daniel?” And he answered, “They are unbroken, O king.”
verses.textLa: Et ait rex: Salvane sunt signacula, Daniel? Qui respondit: Salva, rex.

verses.textEn: And as soon as he had opened the door, the king stared at the table, and cried out with a loud voice, “Great are you, O Bel, and there is not any deceit with you.”
verses.textLa: Statimque cum aperuisset ostium, intuitus rex mensam, exclamavit voce magna: Magnus es Bel, et non est apud te dolus quisquam.

verses.textEn: And Daniel laughed, and he held back the king, so that he would not enter, and he said, “Look at the pavement, notice whose footsteps these are.”
verses.textLa: Et risit Daniel: et tenuit regem ne ingrederetur intro: et dixit: Ecce pavimentum, animadverte cuius vestigia sint hæc.

verses.textEn: And the king said, “I see the footsteps of men, and women, and children.” And the king was angry.
verses.textLa: Et dixit rex: Video vestigia virorum, et mulierum, et infantium. Et iratus est rex.

verses.textEn: Then he apprehended the priests, and their wives, and their sons, and they showed him the secret doors through which they entered and consumed the things that were on the table.
verses.textLa: Tunc apprehendit sacerdotes, et uxores, et filios eorum: et ostenderunt ei abscondita ostiola, per quæ ingrediebantur, et consumebant quæ erant super mensam.

verses.textEn: Therefore, the king slaughtered them and delivered Bel into the power of Daniel, who overturned him and his temple.
verses.textLa: Occidit ergo illos rex, et tradidit Bel in potestatem Danielis: qui subvertit eum, et templum eius.
verses.notes: The king “occidit,” that is, slaughtered them. He did not interfecit, put them to death by execution. In other words, the king did not give them a trial, nor send them to prison to await formal execution. He merely ordered their immediate deaths by his soldiers.

verses.textEn: And there was a great dragon in that place, and the Babylonians worshipped him.
verses.textLa: Et erat draco magnus in loco illo, et colebant eum Babylonii.
verses.notes: The word draco, dragon, can also mean snake. It most likely refers to some unusual type of animal kept by the Babylonians. This was not so unusual. The Roman leaders used to obtain and keep unusual animals from far off lands, including lions and other animals brought to Rome from Africa.

verses.textEn: And the king said to Daniel, “Behold, now you cannot say that this is not a living god; therefore, adore him.”
verses.textLa: Et dixit rex Danieli: Ecce nunc non potes dicere quia iste non sit Deus vivens: adora ergo eum.

verses.textEn: And Daniel said, “I adore the Lord, my God, for he is the living God. But that one is not a living god.
verses.textLa: Dixitque Daniel: Dominum Deum meum adoro: quia ipse est Deus vivens: iste autem non est Deus vivens.

verses.textEn: Therefore, you give me the power, O king, and I will execute this dragon without sword or club.” And the king said, “I give it to you.”
verses.textLa: Tu autem rex da mihi potestatem, et interficiam draconem absque gladio, et fuste. Et ait rex: Do tibi.

verses.textEn: And so Daniel took pitch, and fat, and hair, and cooked them together. And he made lumps and put them into the dragon’s mouth, and the dragon burst open. And he said, “Behold, this is what you worship.”
verses.textLa: Tulit ergo Daniel picem, et adipem, et pilos, et coxit pariter: fecitque massas, et dedit in os draconis, et diruptus est draco. Et dixit: Ecce quem colebatis.

verses.textEn: When the Babylonians had heard this, they were greatly indignant. And gathering together against the king, they said, “The king has become a Jew. He has destroyed Bel, he has executed the dragon, and he has slaughtered the priests.”
verses.textLa: Quod cum audissent Babylonii, indignati sunt vehementer: et congregati adversum regem, dixerunt: Iudæus factus est rex: Bel destruxit, draconem interfecit, et sacerdotes occidit.
verses.notes: The dragon’s death was an execution by authority (interfecit), whereas the priests where killed where they stood.

verses.textEn: And when they came to the king, they said, “Deliver Daniel to us, otherwise we will execute you and your house.”
verses.textLa: Et dixerunt cum venissent ad regem: Trade nobis Danielem, alioquin interficiemus te, et domum tuam.
verses.notes: An insurrection is threatened whereby the other leaders in the kingdom would rise up and take power, then put the king to death by a formal execution. They were not threatening merely to kill the king.

verses.textEn: Thus the king saw that they pressured him vehemently, and so, being compelled by necessity, he delivered Daniel to them.
verses.textLa: Vidit ergo rex quod irruerent in eum vehementer: et necessitate compulsus tradidit eis Danielem.

verses.textEn: And they cast him into the den of lions, and he was there for six days.
verses.textLa: Qui miserunt eum in lacum leonum, et erat ibi diebus sex.

verses.textEn: Furthermore, in the den there were seven lions, and they had given to them two carcasses every day, and two sheep, but then they were not given to them, so that they would devour Daniel.
verses.textLa: Porro in lacu erant leones septem, et dabantur eis duo corpora quotidie, et duæ oves: et tunc non data sunt eis, ut devorarent Danielem.

verses.textEn: Now there was in Judea a prophet called Habakkuk, and he had cooked a small meal and had broken bread in a bowl, and he was going into the field, to bring it to the harvesters.
verses.textLa: Erat autem Habacuc propheta in Iudæa, et ipse coxerat pulmentum, et intriverat panes in alveolo: et ibat in campum ut ferret messoribus.

verses.textEn: And the angel of the Lord said to Habakkuk, “Carry the meal that you have into Babylon, to Daniel, who is in the lions’ den.”
verses.textLa: Dixitque Angelus Domini ad Habacuc: Fer prandium, quod habes, in Babylonem Danieli, qui est in lacu leonum.

verses.textEn: And Habakkuk said, “Lord, I have not seen Babylon, and I do not know the den.”
verses.textLa: Et dixit Habacuc: Domine, Babylonem non vidi, et lacum nescio.

verses.textEn: And the angel of the Lord seized him by the top of his head, and carried him by the hair of his head, and set him in Babylon, over the den, by the force of his spirit.
verses.textLa: Et apprehendit eum Angelus Domini in vertice eius, et portavit eum capillo capitis sui, posuitque eum in Babylone supra lacum in impetu spiritus sui.

verses.textEn: And Habakkuk shouted, saying, “Daniel, servant of God, take the dinner that God has sent you.”
verses.textLa: Et clamavit Habacuc, dicens: Daniel serve Dei, tolle prandium, quod misit tibi Deus.

verses.textEn: And Daniel said, “You have remembered me, O God, and you have not abandoned those who love you.”
verses.textLa: Et ait Daniel: Recordatus es mei Deus, et non dereliquisti diligentes te.

verses.textEn: And Daniel arose and ate. And then the angel of the Lord immediately returned Habakkuk to his place.
verses.textLa: Surgensque Daniel comedit. Porro Angelus Domini restituit Habacuc confestim in loco suo.

verses.textEn: And so, on the seventh day, the king came to mourn Daniel. And he came to the den, and gazed in, and behold, Daniel was sitting in the midst of the lions.
verses.textLa: Venit ergo rex die septimo ut lugeret Danielem: et venit ad lacum, et introspexit, et ecce Daniel sedens in medio leonum.

verses.textEn: And the king cried out with a loud voice, saying, “Great are you, O Lord, the God of Daniel.” And he pulled him out of the lions’ den.
verses.textLa: Et exclamavit voce magna rex, dicens: Magnus es Domine Deus Danielis. Et extraxit eum de lacu leonum.

verses.textEn: Furthermore, those who had been the cause of his downfall, he hurled into the den, and they were devoured in a moment before him.
verses.textLa: Porro illos, qui perditionis eius causa fuerant, intromisit in lacum, et devorati sunt in momento coram eo.

verses.textEn: Then the king said, “Let all the inhabitants of the whole earth fear the God of Daniel. For he is the Savior, working signs and miracles on earth, who has freed Daniel from the lions’ den.”
verses.textLa: Tunc rex ait: Paveant omnes habitantes in universa terra Deum Danielis: quia ipse est Salvator, faciens signa, et mirabilia in terra: qui liberavit Danielem de lacu leonum.
verses.notes: The word mirabilia means wonders or miracles.
